#Text=Isaq Schrijver
#Text=Isaq Schrijver ( fl. 1689 – 1705/06 ) was a Dutch ensign and South African explorer .
#Text=Although born and raised in Leiden , both his parents were born near Aachen , Germany .
#Text=Little else is known of his origins , but by 1667 he was a marine .
#Text=In February 1684 , Schrijver , then a sergeant in the Dutch East India Company and stationed at the Cape , headed a reconnaissance expedition into Namaqualand .
#Text=They went as far north as Garies and brought back samples of copper ore to Cape Town .
#Text=Schrijver was involved in salvage operations of the Nossa Senhora dos Milagros which had run aground on the night of 16 April 1686 at Struisbaai near Cape Agulhas .

#Text=This was a Portuguese vessel with 150 crew , commanded by Don Emmanual Da Silva , en route from Goa to Portugal and bearing diplomatic gifts from Narai , King of Siam to Pedro , King of Portugal , Louis XIV of France and Charles II of England .
#Text=Also aboard were three Siamese ambassadors who were left to fend for themselves by the crew .

#Text=Two were found in a desperate state a month after the wreck , the third having succumbed . [ 1 ] Simon van der Stel sent a party consisting of lieutenant Olof Bergh , Isaq Schrijver and others to salvage what they could .

#Text=Very little of any value was returned to the governor , but rumours of theft of the treasure soon started circulating , substantiated by the attempted sale of items to Cape Town residents and the unearthing in Olof Bergh 's garden of a box holding objects from the wreck .
#Text=Bergh later confessed to the theft and alleged that van der Stel himself was involved .
#Text=Bergh was sentenced to three and a half years on Robben Island while Schrijver was cleared of any wrongdoing .
#Text=On 4 January 1689 , two years after being promoted to the rank of ensign , Schrijver embarked on his most enterprising expedition .
#Text=His orders were to barter cattle with the Inqua Hottentots of the Eastern Cape .
#Text=He set off with a party of about 20 well-armed soldiers and 2 wagons on a trip which would cover about 1600km .

#Text=Also in the party was Heinrich Bernhard Oldenland ( 1663 – 99 ) , an able botanist and expert on herbs , who had studied medicine for 3 years at Leiden University , and who would in 1693 be appointed as master gardener in the Company 's garden in Cape Town , and oddly as land surveyor for the Government followed by the post of superintendent of roads , bridges and buildings .

#Text=The mission lasted more than three months and reached as far east as the present-day town of Aberdeen , returning on 10 April 1689 with about a thousand head of cattle from trading with a Xhosa - Khoi tribe and quite amazingly having suffered no loss of life .
#Text=Early travelers were obliged to cross the Outeniqua Mountains near present-day Mossel Bay so as to avoid the near-impenetrable ravines and forests to the east .
#Text=At that time the only way across the mountains was through Attaquas Kloof , named after a chief of the Hessequa Khoikhoi .
#Text=This route was pioneered by Schrijver who , following an elephant track , traversed the kloof to the Olifants River in January 1689 .
#Text=The Duivenhoks River at Heidelberg was named by Schrijver , and " Schrijvershoek " near Langebaan lagoon was named after him .

#Text=He retired in 1699 to his farm Schoongezicht near Stellenbosch - the farm was substantially enlarged by the addition of surrounding property that had formed part of the deceased estates of freed slaves .

#Text=Schoongezicht ' s history goes back to 1692 when Simon van der Stel , Governor of the Cape , granted 17 hectares of land to freed slaves Manuel and Antonia of Angola , Louis of Bengal and Isaac Schryver .
#Text=Schrijver married Marie Elizabeth van Coningshoven .
#Text=Soon after , Schryver travelled north once again to search for copper .
#Text=He returned after a few years and finally died on the farm , survived by Marie Elizabeth , who later married Jacob Groenewald .
#Text=The farm remained in the family ownership for some 100 years .
#Text=Schoongezicht passed through numerous hands in the three centuries of its existence .
#Text=Coenraad Fick built the gabled Cape Dutch home about 1830 .
#Text=In the 1920s a Mrs. English bought the estate , restored the buildings , and improved the vineyards , renaming it Lanzerac after a wine-growing region in France .
#Text=In 1958 the entrepreneur David Rawdon converted the estate into a successful hotel .
#Text=In 1990 business tycoon Christo Wiese purchased the property , converting it into a winery and hotel . [ 2 ]
#Text=Contemporary copies of Schrijver 's journals of the expeditions have survived and are now kept in the Cape Archives .
#Text=References
#Text=Standard Encyclopaedia of Southern Africa ( vol.9 ) - NASOU , ( Cape Town 1973 )
#Text=Mossop , E.E. Journals of the expeditions of the Honourable Ensigns Olof Bergh ( 1682 and 1683 ) and Isaq Schrijver ( 1689 ) .
#Text=Van Riebeeck Society , Cape Town , 1931 .
